title: 107_s1541
content:
The "Temporary Emergency Unemployment Compensation Act of 2001" can be cited as the short title. Federal-State agreements are addressed in the act. The "Temporary Emergency Unemployment Compensation Act of 2001" allows states to enter agreements with the Secretary of Labor to provide temporary emergency unemployment compensation to individuals who have exhausted regular compensation rights. The "Temporary Emergency Unemployment Compensation Act of 2001" allows states to provide temporary emergency unemployment compensation to individuals who have exhausted all rights to regular compensation under State law, have no rights to compensation for a week under any unemployment compensation law, and are not receiving compensation under the unemployment compensation law of Canada. An individual is deemed to have exhausted regular compensation rights when no payments can be made under the law because they have received all regular benefits. The "Temporary Emergency Unemployment Compensation Act of 2001" allows states to provide temporary emergency unemployment compensation to individuals who have exhausted all rights to regular compensation under State law. An individual is deemed to have exhausted regular compensation rights when no payments can be made under the law because they have received all regular benefits available. The "Temporary Emergency Unemployment Compensation Act of 2001" allows states to provide temporary emergency unemployment compensation to individuals who have exhausted all rights to regular compensation under State law. The weekly benefit amount for total unemployment is equal to the regular compensation payable under the State law. Terms and conditions of the State law apply to claims for temporary emergency unemployment compensation, except where inconsistent with the Act. The State law terms and conditions apply to claims for temporary emergency unemployment compensation, with a maximum amount payable to individuals. States can elect to trigger off an extended compensation period. An emergency unemployment compensation account is established for individuals, with the Governor of a State authorized to trigger off an extended compensation period for those who have exhausted regular compensation rights under State law. SEC. 3. TEMPORARY EMERGENCY UNEMPLOYMENT COMPENSATION ACCOUNT. The State will establish temporary emergency unemployment compensation accounts for eligible individuals, with the amount in the account being 13 times the individual's average weekly benefit amount for the benefit year. This amount may be reduced by any extended compensation received under the Federal-State Extended Unemployment Compensation Act of 1970. The individual's temporary emergency unemployment compensation account will be reduced by any extended compensation received under the Federal-State Extended Unemployment Compensation Act of 1970. The weekly benefit amount is the regular compensation payable for total unemployment. SEC. 4. PAYMENTS TO STATES WITH AGREEMENTS FOR TEMPORARY EMERGENCY UNEMPLOYMENT COMPENSATION. Payments to states with agreements for temporary emergency unemployment compensation shall be equal to 100 percent of the compensation paid to individuals under the agreement. States will not receive payment for compensation already reimbursed under other federal laws. The amount payable to each state with an agreement will be determined accordingly. Sums payable to states with agreements for temporary emergency unemployment compensation will be determined by the Secretary in advance or by reimbursement. The estimates will be based on the Secretary's calculations for each calendar month, adjusted for any discrepancies from prior months. The payment amounts will be based on agreed-upon methods between the Secretary and the state agency. SEC. 5. FINANCING PROVISIONS. Funds from the extended unemployment compensation account in the Unemployment Trust Fund are used to make payments to States with agreements under this title. The Secretary certifies payments to each State, which are then transferred from the extended unemployment compensation account to the State's account in the Unemployment Trust Fund. Appropriations are made to provide assistance to States. Prior to audit or settlement, payments are made to States from the extended unemployment compensation account in the Unemployment Trust Fund. Appropriations are provided to assist States in meeting administration costs under this title. Authorization of appropriations is made for certain payments to the extended unemployment compensation account. Authorization of appropriations is provided from the general fund of the Treasury to the extended unemployment compensation account in the Unemployment Trust Fund for specific payments without a fiscal year limitation. The Secretary estimates the necessary sums for payments under this section for compensation under chapter 85 of title 5, United States Code, and compensation based on services covered by section 3309(a)(1) of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. Amounts appropriated do not need to be repaid. SEC. 6. FRAUD AND OVERPAYMENTS. Individuals who knowingly make false statements or fail to disclose material facts to receive unauthorized temporary emergency unemployment compensation will be ineligible for further benefits and may face prosecution under section 1001 of title 18, United States Code. Repayment is required for those who have received such benefits. Individuals who received unauthorized temporary emergency unemployment compensation must repay the amounts to the State agency unless repayment is waived due to no fault on their part or if repayment would be unjust. The State agency may pursue recovery of these funds. The State agency may waive repayment of unauthorized emergency unemployment compensation if it was not the individual's fault and repayment would be unfair. The agency can recover the amount by deducting from future unemployment benefits for up to three years. The State agency may waive repayment of unauthorized emergency unemployment compensation if it was not the individual's fault. Repayment can be recovered by deducting from future unemployment benefits for up to three years, with a maximum deduction of 50 percent of the weekly benefit amount. No repayment or deduction can be made without a fair hearing and a final determination. The State agency may waive repayment of unauthorized emergency unemployment compensation if it was not the individual's fault. Repayment can be recovered by deducting from future unemployment benefits for up to three years, with a maximum deduction of 50 percent of the weekly benefit amount. No repayment or deduction can be made without a fair hearing and a final determination. Any determination by a State agency under this section shall be subject to review in the same manner and to the same extent as determinations under the State unemployment compensation law. SEC. 7. DEFINITIONS. Terms such as "compensation", "benefit year", and "week" are defined under the Federal-State Extended Unemployment Compensation Act of 1970.

SEC. 8. APPLICABILITY. Agreements under this Act apply to weeks of unemployment starting after the agreement and ending within 18 months of enactment.

SEC. 9. TEMPORARY REDUCTION IN INTEREST RATE FOR STATE UNEMPLOYMENT FUNDS. SEC. 9. TEMPORARY REDUCTION IN INTEREST RATE APPLICABLE TO REPAYMENTS OF ADVANCES TO STATE UNEMPLOYMENT FUNDS. The interest rate paid by a State on advances under the Social Security Act will be reduced from 10 percent to 5 percent for 18 months after the enactment of this Act.
